
# Retrieving data from BioMart

The package,`biomaRt`, provides an interface to a collection of databases implementing the [BioMart suite](http://www.biomart.org).<br>
It enables the retrieval of data from a range of BioMart databases, such as Ensembl (genes and genomes), Uniprot (information on proteins), HGNC (gene nomenclature), Gramene (plant functional genomics), and Wormbase (information on C. elegans and other nematodes).


```R
source("http://www.bioconductor.org/biocLite.R")
```

    Bioconductor version 3.6 (BiocInstaller 1.28.0), ?biocLite for help
    


```R
biocLite("biomaRt")
```

    BioC_mirror: https://bioconductor.org
    Using Bioconductor 3.6 (BiocInstaller 1.28.0), R 3.4.2 (2017-09-28).
    Installing package(s) 'biomaRt'
    

    package 'biomaRt' successfully unpacked and MD5 sums checked
    
    The downloaded binary packages are in
    	C:\Users\Administrator\AppData\Local\Temp\RtmpgLhI2B\downloaded_packages
    

    Old packages: 'backports', 'broom', 'caret', 'curl', 'data.table', 'digest',
      'DRR', 'foreach', 'glue', 'haven', 'hexbin', 'hms', 'htmlwidgets',
      'iterators', 'knitr', 'lava', 'lazyeval', 'lubridate', 'MASS', 'Matrix',

```R
library('biomaRt')
# before using the 'biomaRt' package, it is important to install the package and load it into the R session
```

Here, select an appropriate mart for retrieval by defining the right database for a query we want. And we will look for 'human ensembl genes'; using the `useMart` function as follows:


```R
mart <- useMart(biomart = "ensembl", dataset = "hsapiens_gene_ensembl")
mart
# 'useMart' function is used to choose 'ensembl' database
```


    Object of class 'Mart':
      Using the ENSEMBL_MART_ENSEMBL BioMart database
      Using the hsapiens_gene_ensembl dataset



```R
my_results <- getBM(attributes = c("hgnc_symbol"), mart = mart)
# get the list of genes from the ensembl data
```


```R
N <- 50
mysample <- sample(my_results$hgnc_symbol,N)
head(mysample)
# sample 50 genes from the retrieved genes
```


<ol class=list-inline>
	<li>'WNK1'</li>
	<li>'SVOPL'</li>
	<li>'BANK1'</li>
	<li>'NEIL3'</li>
	<li>'TGM6'</li>
	<li>'MIR621'</li>
</ol>



The `biomaRt` package can also be used to retrieve sequences from the databases for a gene, namely "BRCA1"


```R
seq <- getSequence(id="BRCA1", type="hgnc_symbol", seqType="peptide", mart = mart)
show(seq)
```

```R
seq2 <- getSequence(id="ENST00000520540", type='ensembl_transcript_id',seqType='gene_flank',upstream = 30,mart = mart)
# retrieve a sequence that specifies the chromosome position, 'upstream' and 'downstream' from a site can be used as well
seq2
show(seq2)
```


<table>
<thead><tr><th scope=col>gene_flank</th><th scope=col>ensembl_transcript_id</th></tr></thead>
<tbody>
	<tr><td>AATGAAAAGAGGTCTGCCCGAGCGTGCGAC</td><td>ENST00000520540               </td></tr>
</tbody>
</table>



                          gene_flank ensembl_transcript_id
    1 AATGAAAAGAGGTCTGCCCGAGCGTGCGAC       ENST00000520540
    

Thus, the `biomaRt` package can search the database and fetch a variety of biological data. Although the data can be downloaded in a conventional way from its respective database, `biomaRt` can be used to bring the element of automation into your workflow for bulk and
batch processing.<br>
The `biomaRt` package can also be used to convert one gene ID to other types of IDs.

* The BioMart home page at http://www.biomart.org to know more about BioMart
* The BioMart: driving a paradigm change in biological data management article by Arek Kasprzyk (http://database.oxfordjournals.org/content/2011/bar049.full)
* The BioMart and Bioconductor: a powerful link between biological databases and microarray data analysis article by Durinck and others (http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/content/21/16/3439.long), which discusses the details of the biomaRt package.
